{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's symptoms of rapid, shallow breathing, anxiety, tachycardia, hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distention following a stab wound to the chest suggest cardiac tamponade. This condition occurs when blood or fluid fills the space between the sac that encases the heart and the heart muscle, putting pressure on the heart and affecting its function. One of the classic signs of cardiac tamponade is pulsus paradoxus, which is a drop in systolic blood pressure of more than 10 mmHg during inspiration. This is because the pressure inside the chest decreases during inspiration, allowing more blood to flow into the right side of the heart. However, because the heart is compressed by the fluid in the pericardial sac, it cannot expand to accommodate this increased volume of blood.
